problems.title: Perform Binary Search on Sorted Array
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given an integer N and a sorted array A of N integers in non-decreasing order. You are also given an integer X. Your task is to determine whether X exists in the array using the Binary Search algorithm.
Binary Search works by repeatedly dividing the search interval into halves. If the target value X is equal to the middle element, return its index. If X is smaller, search in the left half; otherwise, search in the right half.
If X exists in the array, return its index (0-based). Otherwise, return -1.

Input Format
The first line contains an integer N.
The second line contains N sorted integers representing the array A.
The third line contains the integer X to search.

Output Format
Print a single integer: the index of X if found, otherwise -1.

Example 1
Input:
7
1 3 5 7 9 11 13
7

Output:
3

Explanation:
The number 7 is found at index 3 using binary search.
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5
-10^9 ≤ A[i], X ≤ 10^9
Array is guaranteed to be sorted in non-decreasing order.

problems.title: Find First Element ≥ X in Sorted Array
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given an integer N and a sorted array A of N integers (sorted in non-decreasing order). You are also given an integer X.
Your task is to find the first element in the array that is greater than or equal to X.
If such an element exists, print its value. If no such element exists, print -1.
This can be efficiently solved using binary search (lower bound technique).

Input Format
The first line contains an integer N.
The second line contains N space-separated sorted integers representing array A.
The third line contains the integer X.

Output Format
Print the first element in A that is ≥ X, otherwise print -1.

Example 1
Input:
7
1 3 5 7 9 11 13
6

Output:
7

Explanation:
The first element that is ≥ 6 is 7.
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5
-10^9 ≤ A[i], X ≤ 10^9
Array is sorted in non-decreasing order.

If low goes out of range (low == N), no such element exists.

problems.title: Find Last Element ≤ X in Sorted Array
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given an integer N and a sorted array A of N integers (sorted in non-decreasing order). You are also given an integer X.
Your task is to find the last element in the array that is less than or equal to X.
If such an element exists, print its value. If no such element exists, print -1.
This can be solved efficiently using binary search (upper bound technique).

Input Format
The first line contains an integer N.
The second line contains N space-separated sorted integers representing array A.
The third line contains the integer X.

Output Format
Print the last element in A that is ≤ X, otherwise print -1.

Example 1
Input:
7
1 3 5 7 9 11 13
6

Output:
5

Explanation:
The last element that is ≤ 6 is 5.
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5
-10^9 ≤ A[i], X ≤ 10^9
Array is sorted in non-decreasing order.

If high becomes -1, then no element ≤ X exists.

problems.title: Check if Perfect Square Exists in Sorted Array
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given an integer N and a sorted array A of N integers (sorted in non-decreasing order). Your task is to check whether the array contains at least one perfect square.
A perfect square is a number whose square root is an integer (e.g., 0, 1, 4, 9, 16...).
If any element is a perfect square, print "YES". If none of the elements is a perfect square, print "NO".

Input Format
The first line contains an integer N.
The second line contains N space-separated sorted integers representing array A.

Output Format
Print "YES" if a perfect square exists, otherwise print "NO".

Example 1
Input:
6
1 3 5 9 12 15

Output:
YES

Explanation:
The element 9 is a perfect square (3 × 3).
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5
0 ≤ A[i] ≤ 10^12
Array is sorted in non-decreasing order.

problems.title: Binary Search on Descending Sorted Array
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given an integer N and an array A of N integers sorted in strictly descending order. You are also given an integer X. Your task is to find the index of X in this descending sorted array using Binary Search.
Binary search on descending arrays works with reversed comparisons:
- If A[mid] == X → return mid
- If A[mid] < X → search in the left half
- If A[mid] > X → search in the right half
If X does not exist in the array, return -1.

Input Format
The first line contains an integer N.
The second line contains N space-separated integers sorted in descending order.
The third line contains the integer X to search.

Output Format
Print the index of X (0-based), or -1 if not found.

Example 1
Input:
6
20 17 15 10 8 3
10

Output:
3

Explanation:
10 is found at index 3 in the descending array.
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5
-10^9 ≤ A[i], X ≤ 10^9
Array is strictly sorted in descending order.
